bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, January 30, 1942

div1.p: Hench encloses a check to purchase additional land from the site of Camp Lazear. He is surprised to hear that nothing has been done to Building No. 1, since he had sent some money to Moran for repairs months ago. Hench makes note of his correspondence with Ponce and his influence with the Cuban government.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Adrian Macia, January 30, 1942
div1.opener:
Rochester, Minnesota
January 30, 1942
Senor Adrian Macia
Manzana de Gomez 325
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senor Macia:
div1.p:
I appreciate greatly your letter of January 6 which arrived just
before I went East for two weeks in Washington. I appreciate the answers to my
questions and am enclosing a check for $150.00 to purchase 150 square yards of
land as per your letter of January 6. I assume, of course, that this land com-
prises the land now occupied by the little shack (Building No. 1). I also appre-
ciate that this isn't a very large amount of land and wondered how near it comes
to the former site of Building No. 2, where we saw the remains of the concrete
floor. I am anxious to obtain legal possession of at least enough of this land
to preserve our little building. Because of the war it may be more difficult
to accomplish rapidly our complete purpose in raising the money for this memorial
but I am anxious to protect it against further encroachment of the quarry, etc.
and most sincerely appreciate your real and personal interest in this venture.
I would appreciate it if you would discuss the matter further with your partners
so that we can know whether they would be willing to join you in presenting more
of the site of Camp Lazear for our project.

All he
woned
tell me
now.

I am surprised to hear that nothing has been done to the house.
Some months ago I sent Mr. Moran a check for $50.00 with which he was going to have
some repairs done to the porch and roof. The check has been cashed and returned
but perhaps he has been ill or has had difficulty in arranging this. I plan to
write him. I appreciate your estimate of the cost of the materials to build the
type of memorial building I had in mind, and as soon as you can give me information
as to the cost of the land I will be able to present a more formal program to those
of my friends who are interested in this project. May I hope, therefore, that you
will write to me shortly about this?

I have just received a letter from Dr. Felipe Carbonell Ponce of
Havana. He noted my paper on “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” in the Proceedings of
the Mayo Clinic Staff Meetings, a copy of which I enclose. This inspired him to
get in touch with Mr. Salas who apparently owns a Havana radio station, and he and
Mr. Salas as I understand it interviewed President Batista and Dr. Marruz, acting
Minister of Health, proposing that the Cuban government become interested in this
venture. Just how far they have got or will get, I have no knowledge. I shall be
very grateful to you if you would give me your confidential opinion regarding Dr.
Ponce, whether he is an outstanding Havana physician of the high type which we would
want to be associated with this venture. Knowing how tentative government projects
in our own country are so long delayed in passage and accomplishment I do not wish
to rely too greatly on the efforts of Dr. Ponce and wish to go ahead with my
arrangements with you and with our arrangements here. If, happily, Dr. Ponce should
really interest the Cuban government in our project, I can assure you it would give
me great pleasure to hand over any ideas and property which I might have and in the
meantime might obtain from you. It would be the greatest pleasure to hand to the
Cuban government gratis any interest I have in the project but I do want to see that
it is put through properly for all concerned.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
